description: French arcade, from Italian arcata (“arch of a bridge”), from Latin arcus (“arc”).

entries.meaning: (architecture) A covered passage, usually with shops on both sides.
An establishment that runs coin-operated games.

verbs.description: arcade (third-person singular simple present arcades, present participle arcading, simple past and past participle arcaded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover (something) as with a series of arches.
examples: 1873, Thomas Mayne Reid, The Death Shot, London: Chapman and Hall, Volume 1, Chapter 25, p. 224,[1]

its trottoirs brick-paved, and shaded by trees of almost tropical foliage— conspicuous among them the odoriferous magnolia, and the melia azedarach, or “Pride of China,”—these in places completely arcading the street—
